titleInfo.subTitle: Elsie Mae Stallworth Hebert oral history interview, 1993

name.description: Elsie Hebert was born in 1925 to Oscar and Iva Mae Boone; she was an only child. She attended Monte Sano Elementary School and Baker High School. Hebert received a bachelor's degree in journalism from Louisiana State University in 1945 and continued her studies there, receiving a master's degree in 1948. After working as a reporter and editor for various newspapers and news programs and teaching for several years at Nicholls State University, she returned to LSU in 1966. She was hired to teach in the English Department and soon became the faculty adviser to the Reveille. She later transitioned into a teaching position with the journalism school where she taught for thirty-five years. She earned a doctorate from the University of Texas at Austin during her first few years as a journalism professor at LSU. She was married to A. Otis Hebert and had two sons. Hebert passed away in 2012.

mods.abstract: Elsie Hebert talks about her choice to attend LSU and study journalism. She discusses the professional fields available for women at that time, dress codes, classes, the Reveille, the journalism school faculty, and her classmates. Hebert describes campus life and calling LSU her home. She discusses her degrees and working for LSU as a professor and adviser to the Reveille. She talks about changes in the journalism school and discusses what LSU meant to her.
